subject: Re: [junit] Test genes, test infected rates, and test-resistant managers

messageBody:
One missing link:

1) "All Objects of a given type that are .equals should return equal
.hashCodes" Well, here's my self-plug. This statement could be
handled by a Theory runner, like Marat and I described at

http://shareandenjoy.saff.net/2006/12/new-paper-practice-of-theories.html

Thanks,

David Saff

On 1/29/07, David Saff <saff@...> wrote:
> Alberto,
>
> There are all sorts of things that keep developers from testing their
> own code, and you touched on some of them. Here's some other
> thoughts, mostly around the technology for testing.
>
> Many developers like the idea of testing their own code, but just
> don't see how they can in their particular situation. One of the most
> gratifying moments I've had as a consultant was being able to go from
> bug report to failing acceptance test to failing unit test to code fix
> to passing unit test to passing acceptance test to check-in to bug
> fixed in about 20-30 minutes while my team-mates watched on a
> projector. This kick-started a lot of interest in developer testing,
> and TDD, that hadn't been there before. As a matter of fact, my first
> meeting with the team had actually contained the exchange:
>
> "You can't test that"
> "If you watch, I'll show how we could..."
> "No, you can't"
> "Yes, we can!"
>
> It took about a month and several dozen bug fixes (client-facing bugs,
> mind you) to get familiar with each other and patch up the design for
> testability before the above could happen. This would have been a
> big, risky investment, if the manager hadn't bought in to the idea
> beforehand. Ironically, for someone familiar with the wider landscape
> of software methodology, some teams are simply too focused on
> incremental results to justify that kind of Big Cleanup Up Front.
> What can we do for them? I'd like to see tools that move us toward a
> world where if you can easily think it, you can easily write the test.
> What kinds of things can I easily think, but not easily test?
>
> 1) "All Objects of a given type that are .equals should return equal
> .hashCodes" Well, here's my self-plug. This statement could be
> handled by a Theory runner, like Marat and I described at
>
> 2) "This package should have the same behavior today that it did when
> we released version 3.2." We're getting there. JUnitFactory
> (http://www.junitfactory.com) does a good job of generating JUnit
> tests where none exist. If you generate tests on version 3.2, you can
> run them on today's version, and catch a lot of regressions. [Full
> disclosure: I'm a research fellow at Agitar, which produces JUnit
> Factory. It's still very cool.]
>
> 3) "During debugging, I noticed that thisUser.password was null. It
> should have been 'myPassword', instead." There are research debuggers
> that allow statements like this to be built and verified, but we're
> still waiting for them to reach the mainstream.
>
> 4) "I can't call my code directly without an packagex.HttpContext and
> a packagex.UserSession and a..." This is possibly the biggest failing
> of library and framework providers today. The ability to test code
> that depends on Package X is an important part of Package X's
> functionality, but it far too often is left to the developer of the
> package's client programs to create a testing harness, often with a
> lot of work. Ruby on Rails ships with a built-in testing framework,
> which I think has part of the success of the framework itself and its
> integrators. Ditto for Eclipse's plug-in development environment. In
> my experience so far, Java web frameworks are way behind in this, but
> I'd be happy to find out that there is a framework that ships with a
> usable test framework. However, I think we can go even farther
> here--these frameworks are both better suited to acceptance tests than
> isolated unit tests.
>
> In the end, I think that if developer testing scores a Major Victory,
> it may end up being a developer-driven victory, more like version
> control or automated builds, rather than a manager-driven victory,
> like QA (of course an over-simplification).
>
> David Saff
>
> On 1/23/07, albsavoia <albsavoia@...> wrote:
> >
> > I am still surprised that, as we near the 10th, anniversary of JUnit
> > (later this year) developer/unit testing, despite its obvious benefits
> > and the fact that "it's the right thing to do", is still only practiced
> > by a minority of developers in a minority of organizations. And, by
> > practiced I mean, SERIOUSLY practiced. I talk with a lot of groups who
> > say they *do* unit testing but have just a handful of test, rarely run,
> > and no consistency, idea of code coverage, etc.
> >
> > I gave talks on JUnit and the developer testing revolution at two
> > JavaOne conferences (2004 and 2006) where I talked about the three
> > possible outcomes for the future of developer/unit testing:
> >
> >
> > Long-Term Defeat: Theidea of developer testing was a noble, notable,
> > but ultimately short-lived blipin the history of software development.
> > Almost all developers went back to the old way of thinking: testing
> > isfor QA.
> >
> >
> >
> > Minor Victory: Developer testing does not disappear, but it remains a
> > nicheactivity. Practiced only by a devoutminority of test-infected
> > developers.
> >
> >
> >
> > Major Victory: Developer testing becomes a standardsoftware development
> > practice. The rule,instead of the exception. Releasingsoftware without
> > unit/developer testing is as unthinkable as releasing softwarewithout
> > QA.
> >
> > I am rooting, of course, for the major victory, but I am starting to
> > have my doubts, and wondering why progress is so slow. Below is my
> > analysis of what I believe is happening and I'd be very interested in
> > your opinion.
> >
> > In the past few years, I've noticed that some developers are easily
> > "test-infected", others require longer exposure and some encouragement
> > but eventually "get it" , and one group seems to have a built-in
> > immunity.
> >
> > It's as if there are 3 basic types of test genes:
> >
> > T1 - Very susceptpible to test infection. Show them a single JUnit
> > example and they get it immediately - and start using it regularly and
> > with great fervor. When time pressure hits, they fight hard for enough
> > time to test and would rather quit than produce code without tests.
> > They often have framed pictures of Kent Beck on their desk :-).
> >
> > T2 - Somewhat susceptible to test infection. Show them how to use
> > JUnit/TDD, give them some encouragement and time to appreciate the
> > benefits and rewards; eventually they will become regular users. When
> > time pressure hits, however, they often revert to no-test mode without
> > too much kicking and screaming.
> >
> > T3 - Immune to test infection. There's no amount of showing and
> > convincing that will get them to practice developer testing on their own
> > with any regularity - if at all. Many of them would rather quit than
> > have to write tests on a regular basis.
> >
> > I would love to be able to say that these genes are somewhat evenly
> > distributed. A rough Gaussian distribution. Something like this:
> >
> > T1: 30%
> > T2: 40%
> > T3: 30%
> >
> > But my experience is that developers with the T3 gene outnumber the
> > combined number of those with T2 and T1 gene.
> >
> > This spells trouble because I have also found that when developers
> > become managers they bring with them their attitudes toward developer
> > testing. And a T3 manager is not going to provide an environment where
> > the T2 (the ones that require some time and encouragement) can become
> > test infected. And this might explain why developer testing is still
> > practiced by a minority of developers in a minority of organizations.
> >
> > Feedback?
> >
> > Alberto
> >

> > Send us Java. Get back JUnit.
